supporting_text: The control of antimicrobial resistance calls for extensive operations comprising society as a whole, taking both humans, animals, plants, foodstuffs, and the environment into consideration in line with the One Health approach.
The NAP mentions specific actions in the human health sector, including preparing national recommendations for infection prevention at hospitals and long-term care facilities.

The NAP includes actions related to enhancing the surveillance of resistance related to animal pathogens and producing targeted information on the resistance situation to veterinarians and animal owners.
The NAP discusses the environmental impacts of antimicrobial substances and the need for monitoring and controlling their release into the environment.
The NAP addresses the use of antimicrobials in food production and includes actions to monitor and control antimicrobial use in agriculture.
The NAP includes a model for the follow-up of the implementation of the actions and mentions the annual task of assessing the implementation of the programme.
The NAP sets objectives and records actions to achieve the objectives, indicating a structured approach to tracking progress.
The document does not specify quantitative targets for AMR prevalence or antimicrobial use.
The NAP does not mention specific budget allocations for the strategies or actions.
The document does not provide an assessment of future budget requirements.
The NAP mentions the consolidation of operations of the national expert group (MTKA) for AMR coordination.
The NAP aims to enhance legislative development on antimicrobials, veterinary medicines, and medicated feeds at the EU and national level.
The NAP includes actions to enhance training of professionals and education of the general public regarding antimicrobial resistance.
The NAP proposes to increase public education on the significance of tourism in the spreading of antimicrobial resistance.
The NAP emphasizes the importance of international cooperation and commitment to the prevention of AMR across all sectors.
The NAP includes actions to develop real-time notification and reporting systems for antimicrobial resistance.
The NAP highlights the need for rapid identification of extremely resistant antimicrobial bacteria to launch control measures.
The NAP includes actions to prepare national recommendations for infection prevention at hospitals and long-term care facilities.
The NAP aims to enhance administrative cooperation and ensure the inclusion of combat against AMR in the legislation of the appropriate administrative sectors.
The NAP includes actions to prepare a national antimicrobial manual for outpatient healthcare covering choices, dosage, and duration of treatment.
The NAP emphasizes the prudent use of antimicrobials and includes actions to promote rational use in both human and veterinary medicine.
The NAP proposes applied R&D projects focusing on AMR diagnostics and infectious disease diagnostics.
